text: The Permian mass extinction event that killed off most species on Earth at the time was caused when volcanic activity led to a rise of only about 9 degrees. Once it got to that point, methane deposits in the ocean were released by the warmer water and created runaway warming that caused the extinctions. That methane could be released again and pose a danger to the survival of species now, including humans. Let's please try to avoid getting to that tipping point.

text:
"Climate scientists"? Okay, what sciences qualifies as a climate science? Also, he used the phrase something along of "[when 9 doctors says smoking is bad, why are you listening to the one who says it's okay]"; well, he just shot himself in the fucking foot by saying that, because the vast majority of scientist disagree that it's likely humans contribute in a significant way to global warming. There is not enough conclusive evidence/data, as in they follow EMPIRICAL EVIDENCE, as all scientists should, but something climate researchers usually don't! The world is warming, we should pollute much less, but the 90-97% of [whatever] agree [...]; that movement is more or less bullshit. Sure, humans might be contributing to global warming in a significant way, but that movement is bullshit! Not only do they censor who gets into the "circle" those percentages are based on, but they arbitrary decide if a paper is for or against humans and global warming; EVEN AGAINST the author(s) wishes, when they say it's not saying anything about the matter, for example!

Remember the Ozone danger? Yeah, it was manipulation on the highest level! Media showed pictures of the ozone in the past compared to the that time present date, where the present date had a huge hole. The manipulation was that the difference was that one was at day(side) and the other was at night, and at night, the hole on the night side of the planet will always be huge, because ozone both are drawn and created on the dayside of the planet! OFC the hole would look huge, but they hid all facts about what time of day it was, as it was a "radar map"... Yeah, cause timestamps are never on those!

Humans need to pollute less, not only regarding climate gases, but everything really! We might not have any control of global warming, but we should try to not make more of the planet lifeless or life unagreeable! We have more or less wiped out several species already; before it might have been for other reasons, but today, pure capitalism is perhaps what disagrees the most with being environmentally friendly. What is wrong with using a smartphone for 2 or more years? When companies make products that fail on purpose, just after the warranty is out, or doesn't really offer warranty, perhaps just blames the customer no matter what;we get a lot of waste from that sector alone, for those and other reasons... Waste is one of the biggest problems, and it also creates a lot of climate gasses too, so try to be more attentive to that side as a citizen of your country :)

text:
A warming climate means a longer growing season in Canada and much of Russia becoming open for farming, potentially solving the concerns we have about world hunger.  Oh and it should once again be noted that the world has been hotter than it is right now and humans were not around, yet the Earth survived. Increased heat also means more evaporation from the oceans, which means more rain, which could resolve the issues we have with the drying regions of the planet. For example the Sahara desert has been growing and this is of great concern, but recently there has been an increasing amount of vegetation due to the rainfall and it may very well be the desertification could begin to reverse. Even better we now have several regions on the African continent where the people had experienced years of drought and the increased rainfall is making their lives livable again. 

So yeah, if you're going to report on climate change it's probably a good idea to cover the full spectrum of effects.

text: Excellent way to present globally warming, is to mock people ignorant of it's effects, despite the overwhelming evidence. That said, I don't care about the planet anymore, it will be fine, We, Humans, will be gone and the earth will just go on, life will go on without us and adapt (though many species will perish sadly), and it will just be very, very warm, until the next ice age occurs. It will sort itself out, question is will we be here still? Probably not, certainly not the number of people we have alive now, maybe a generous half, if even. I don't see any change happening until we run very low on fossil fuels, enough to scare people into action, i'd settle for nuclear power at this point in that scenario. Fact is, it's not so much save the planet, or save the environment, it's more like save humans and some other species from going extinct. As I said earlier though.. I just find the effort futile at this point, and would rather just enjoy the time I have left, but keep on fighting the good fight, those who still have the energy to care. I personally, have just given up on people in general, except for a few exceptional people who make me feel like giving people another chance, and then trump opens his mouth again, or a flat-earther posts, or some anti-vax lunatic and I can't be fucking bothered to care again.

text:
Climate changing enabled our species to be here.  Scientific community vs loudest voices for climate change does not denote fact, but loudest bias with regards influence due to human activity.  Water vapour is the 
largest contributing greenhouse gas, which we are unable to influence, more to do with core earth temps and solar (sun) activity.  We influence local climate only, meaning local air quality and local temps.  Local temp example, a green field is now a parking lot, surface temps are hotter and stay warmer on tarmac and cement vs vegetation.  And lastly, hottest on record?  WTF, we have only been measuring temps globally for a fraction of our own existence, let alone the earths.

Stick to the comedy mate.

author: More Please

text:
Mike The Stand Sorry, should've said the bacterias that feed on certain wastes. A lot of the sludge that makes up what we call fossil fuel is from certain fibrous materials that never got eaten after the lifeforms died as there were no bacterias capable of eating that fibrous material for what appears to have been a very long time. An evidently sizeable proportion of organic matter from the remains of dead organisms just sat their without being almost immediately consumed as it would be today, and got buried as time went on.

Hence why there's so much sludge of organic matter buried down there.

Trees are one of the major extractors of carbon from the atmosphere and have always been, that branch of life (the chloroplast branch as opposed to our own mitochondrial branch) has always generated its own energy supply by harvesting carbon from the air, and they also build themselves from it.

A forest fire releases a lot of the carbon that forest had extracted. A large forest fire obviously releases more and there will be a period of time where the carbon is in the air before it gets absorbed again by life which in turn causes the temperature to drop and other mechanisms to switch to extracting carbon instead of releasing stored carbon.

What then is going to be the effect of releasing all the carbon from what was once a planet wide absorption that never got re-released?

Now, I'm not a person who sees this as something that will kill life on earth. Quite the contrary. Life does better in the hotter temperatures our surface might reach and carbon is food for chloroplast based creatures which in turn are food for many mitochondrial creatures. Plus higher temperatures means more water in the atmosphere which means more rain and so forth.

The end result of us making the temperature soar upwards on earth will be more life on earth. Provided we don't over harvest everything and create deserts where rainforests could be.

However, there will be a period where life forms that are not capable of adapting will die off en masse. We might be highly adaptable but other creatures are much much more sensitive to minor shifts in the ecosystem to the point that major shifts are catastrophic. 

This will inevitably lead to a chain of starvation throughout our biome's. 

That and the loss of land is what anyone with a lick of common sense is scared of.

All these apocalypse earth scenarios (i.e. earth will become a new venus) are just as silly as all the denialism that anything we humans would call bad is going to happen.

It's going to get rough and frankly we'll probably end up having a war kick off that makes the world wars look like a playground scuffle because for all the brilliance some humans can display humans in general are fucking stupid.

Your globe is pseudoscience. Go look up the defintion of the word. All of your "proof" isn't based on the scientific method. Because it's not science. 

Take gravity for example. Gravity is your assumed cause. So that makes it the independent variable. But it can't be because you can't manipulate gravity to see if it causes a change in your observed phenomena or the dependent variable. Which in this case would be objects falling. So you cannot establish a cause and effect relationship with gravity and falling objects. That's what science is. Science establishes cause and effect relationships and to do that they use the scientfic method. 

The Cavendish experiment is just pseudoscience. The only fair way to do that experiment would be to have lead balls suspended by nothing in a realm of nothing. Because it's impossible to do without another body of mass present at all times. So the mass of the two balls can't be isolated from other mass to accurately prove that mass attracts mass. 

The scientific method for the cavendish experiment would be as follows. Your dependent variable would be a torsion bar turning and not mass attracting mass. The independent variable would be the mass of the objects. It would be intellectually dishonest to say that the observed phenomena is mass attracting mass. When what you see is a torsion bar turning. You don't see mass attracting mass outside of the Cavendish experiment. I should be able to put a giant wrecking ball next to a ping pong ball and see the ping pong ball move toward the wrecking ball. So many fucking morons!!!  Here is a short little story I wrote in about 20 minutes.  There is literally a ton of evidence in itself if you truly understand what is written...

The short story of a pet rock:

  Once upon time there was a rock.  It was a lonely rock.  Always laying on the groung wishing it could be a piece of sand or perhahps just a tiny pebble.  Alas, Rock was too big, water nor wind could move him.  He admired the pebbles because though nothing but a strong wind could move them, water seemed to sweep them by.  Sand, oh how he dreamed of being sand.  To fly through the air, to swim through the water, oh what a dream it would be.  But Rock is too big, never moving.  As the ground around him erodes, he ever more tortured as more and more smaller materials surface and move away from him.  Oh how Rock wishes he wasn't so big.  Even his size doesn't make him sink, but that which erodes around him exposes more of his size.

  What Rock doesn't realize, is that over time, air and water will soon make him a pebble and then a piece of sand and his dream will come true but he doesn't have the patience for this.  The wind never stops and covers all of Earth, ripping complete sections from each other.  The rain cycle will always continue dropping it's water on the highest slopes so it can travel downard or begin collecting itself at the equilibrium point, sea level.  The sun will always move causing thermal chaos.  Rock will always remain at REST, never being pulled down any farther than the more dense material(land) will allow it and never going up because it is heavier than the surrounding material(air).

  Alas, more time has passed.  So much time has passed that Rock has actually gotten smaller.  Rock also notices a new species.  They are funny looking and they can move themselves.  Oh how Rock wishes he could be one.  Rock is also amazed at how when these creatures step on sand or pebble, they tend to move out of their way and/or get smashed further into the land.  Then Rock sees the creature pick pebble up and throw him.  In Rock's amazement, pebble arches through the air and splashes into the water sinking out of sight, landing on the floor and once again coming to rest until the water decides to move him.  Now Rock is really jealous.  Then all of a sudden the creature eyes Rock!  Rock is nervous.  He doesn't know what to expect.  The creature slowly walks towards Rock, eyeing him all the way.  Rock does what he does best and sits there, motionless.  The creature picks him up.  Rock is amazed!!!  He is in motion!!!  Rock askes the creature, "What are you?".  The creature responds, "I am Human".  The Rock smiles.  The creature then puts rock into his pocket and walks off into the distance...
   
  And all because of Mr. Pressure and his secret friend, Mr. Temperature.  The nerve of them!  Without Mr.  Pressure, Rock would of never formed.  Without Mr. Temperature everything would of remained in a state of equilbrium thereby causing no motion which made Rock jealous to begin with.  It is the constant motion of the sun and it's counterpart Mr. Temperature that causes thermal convection which produces wind which in turns develops pressure at the same time.  You can't have one without the other.  Mr. Pressure creates Mr. Temperature and Mr. Temperature creates Mr. Pressure.   You also can't have a pressurized atmosphere without a container/holder regardless of it's composition...

text:
But no, the change rate at climate change over points is very rapid, ever heard of flash frozen mammoths? If you look at the end of the last major glaciation, the sea levels rose rapidly flooding many areas, which is why we have global stories of floods across all cultures. When the tipping comes, it will be very rapid. To hold the temperature to a 2 degree rise as the IPC suggests, we would have to cut global production and resource usage by about 95%, much better to invest in technologies that enable us to roll with climate change rather than return to medieval levels of living.

CO2 levels have been around the 200 parts per million (ppm) and have recently risen to 400 ppm. Below 150 ppm plants die. The earths average CO2 levels is somewhere around 1000 ppm. Commercial greenhouse growers like to keep CO2 levels of around 800 ppm in order to ensure a good supply of CO2 for the plants and to increase crop yields. Man has been responsible for approximately 34 ppm of the rise from 200 to 400 ppm

Also your comment about the change rate is much faster than it ever was. That is based on the fact that two distinct and disparate data sets are being used. The first one is based on ice core samples, plus geological records where many years are stored close together. Whereas what climate change alarmists are using is data from the past 300 years from temperature gauges in mostly the developed west. Many of the gauges recording the highest increases are due to the fact that towns have expanded and the gauges are no longer rural. Think of heating a pan of water, it heats up very slowly until a critical point is reached, and then you get quick rise to boiling point. That's what happens with climate change.

And no scientist will be funded in the climate sciences unless they at least pay lip service to the man-made climate change myth, and say that they buy into it. Just look at the careers of those who said they saw no evidence in their field, now they always add a proviso.

So yes we are having an effect, but the overall effect is minimal and the climate has always changed. Perhaps try looking up megafauna and dinosaurs to see what a truly hot climate produces.

text:
Rob Plant Errr, we don't have detailed heatmaps from that long ago. At least not in the 'drawn from realtime measurements' that we've have for the last several decades.

Putting that aside, yes there's been hot periods in the past many many many years ago.

Yes, life does eventually adapt to a sudden shift in temperature.

So what?

That's all completely besides the point which is this: As far as we can tell every single one of those warming periods coincided with a mass extinction event, which was then followed over the next age with a diversity shift as different species were able to occupy the vacancies left by all the dead lifeforms.

Entire portions of the foodchain dying off cos it couldn't adapt leads to a trickle on effect down the food chain where all of a sudden many different species go extinct cos they have nothing to eat. Then you have all the other ways species are interconnected and rely on each other for survival, i.e. kill insects and you will indirectly kill plants. There's a level of balance in nature and it doesn't recover immediately when that balance goes tits up.

I'm pretty sure the argument 'but the world's been hot in the past' is going to mean jackshit to anyone starving cos for some reason almost all the nearby food sources in the area disappeared after a starvation shock wave passed through the local eco-system

People have the right to believe in absolutely anything, and (much as I dislike it) people also have the right to try and convince others that their idiotic belief is the truth.  Thing is though is that those of us who actually cherish the intelligence bestowed upon us to use logic, reasoning and judgement (you know, the stuff that distinguishes us from Sea Cucumbers) also have the right to fight back before their brainwashing attempts take hold.

I'm fine with people who think the world is flat, or that the Earth is only 6,000 years old, or that there were no planes involved at 9/11, what agitates me is when they try to recruit others.  If a teacher tried to teach my kids that evolution is a sham and that god created us I would kick his or her cunt in for trying to manipulate my children!

text:
Matthew Law It's the fact we're speeding it up that's the problem.

We humans may be highly adaptable but vast swathes of the biosphere are not. The fear there is that a huge extinction event will trigger (like it appears to have done with previous climate shifts) that will proceed very quickly, leading to a sudden drop in the availability of food, and we constantly need food. We can't just go "let's just do without sufficient food for a few decades or perhaps centuries while waiting for everything to grow into the new norm.".

Then you have the sea level issue. These issues might trigger us going into another bout of all out war for resources, this time with nukes. 

It's not an insignificant problem and we really should be working on slowing it down.

This is ignoring the apocalypse scenario some people think will happen where we'll trigger a temperature spike so high that we've pretty much fucked things even for ourselves

text:
mjwholesales I'm pretty sure that wasn't referring to comedians teasing those who believe something rather easy to prove false. 

Also, while the great powers of the 18th-19th century were monstrously predatory and there were some seriously horrific regimes that cropped up after each of the world wars there's nothing today that quite matches the raw evil of some of the city states and civilisations of biblical times.

Ancient Assyria, which predated Judae, was truly monstrous (rule through fear was their approach) and in the times when the Jews were just one of many small proto-states that cropped up or had a chance to grow in the wake of Assyria's fall, each with their own god-of-their-people, there were a few that tried to copy Assyria's approach to ruling.

Hell, the Romans were pretty damned brutal by our standards and the barbarian Celts and Germanics, who lived in anarchy with the general rule that someone trying to become a King meant everyone else had a duty to band together and kill that would be ruler, used to indulge in the practice of collecting the skulls of they've killed and mounting them in their homes.

We're positively meek by history's standards.

We're getting close to "the meek" inheriting the earth. Unfortunately a lot of people still don't like all that leftist touchy feely crap so we're not there yet

My point is I don't really think the bible writers had our rainbows and unicorns western democracies in mind when that passage was written

text:
Don't make the mistake of worshiping the bible. Bibliolatry is idol worship. I was a Christian for 16 years (Catholic then evangelical) and have discussed this one enough to have my own certainties.

Anyhoo, yes, you can't debunk the truth. Noone can actually prove the world is flat because the fact is it's not. Show me a supposed "proof" and I'll show you the critical fault in it. There's always one or more. Unsurprising because to have a proof that the world is flat you have to have made a mistake. It's simply the way of there being a truth here, which is that the world is a globe.

Vice versa, when it comes to proving the world isn't flat one could do something like travel to an area of the world that's got a steeply rising mountain that goes straight down to sea level with an island that rises quite high itself some 30 50 or 70 or so km off the coast. Oh, and a very good camera and a very clear and decently cool day. 

There's plenty of places like this, south coast of France has a few. I did it at the Canary Isle's on La Palma.

Go up the mountain, making sure to look at the island and take measure of how much you can see (the camera helps for comparison). As you go up more and more will become visible as you are going up to a point where you can see a bit more over the "hump" between you and something far away.

Then you have the uncountable number of other proofs that those with eyes to see can tell means the world must be a globe. The progression of the day across the world (timezones), seasons, dealing with long distance communication, the interesting effects that occur with long distance artillery, so on and so forth.

The world is what it is, and what it is, is largely spherical.

text:
Ann Other Let's put it this way: the St Helens eruption is estimated to have released some 10 million tons of CO2 into the air over its 9 hour eruption.

All of our industries, cars, and other things combined amounts to more than 10 times that a day.

In terms of just CO2 we are equivalent to roughly 10 St Helens eruptions a day, every single day, nonstop.

It's not an insiginificant contribution and the idea is that we're artificially accelerating the warming to a dangerous pace, not that we're the sole thing making it happen.

negatorxx The whole "water doesn't bend" argument is utterly retarded.

Water is a liquid, the very idea of it bending or not bending is nonsense.

You have a sphere with sufficient gravity to dominate all other forces acting on the liquid then the liquid must encase the sphere.

It's like how a ferrofluid must encase the end of a sufficiently strong magnet that is brought into close proximity to the fluid.

Whatever force dominates is the primary thing that dictates what the fluid does and on earth the "force" that is usually the most dominant thing acting on the water is the earths gravity.

author: B M

text:
Buy yourself a telescope; watch the phases of the moon and lunar and solar eclipses. Watch the stars move across the sky using a time- lapse. Go to the opposite hemisphere and see totally different stars overhead; but, sometimes you will notice familiar constellations, except they will appear upside down - Casseopeia will look like a 'w' in the northern hemisphere, but an 'm' in the southern hemisphere. Orion has Betelguese top left, in the northern hemisphere and bottom right in the southern. The moon's craters will also appear upside down. 

Watch the tides roll in and out; notice the seasons of the year; go to different countries and notice the different lengths of day and night and the different height of the sun in the sky. Look through your telescope at the planets and notice how spherical they are - then extrapolate.

Or, just look at the photos taken from space.

text:
Nope, the heliocentric model has had its evidence layed out for centuries - from Erastothenes's calculations and the expeditions to the South Pole to huge parts of modern life relying on technology that only works on a globe in space and livestreams from the ISS. You're rejecting all that evidence, so yours is the claim here. The flat earth is not a null hypothesis.

And I didn't commit a false equivalence fallacy - as I said, you should maybe go learn what those are. I did not in any imply that surface tension had anything to do with a flate or globe-shaped Earth. In fact, I explicitly stated that that wasn't the case. What I wanted to do, and I also explained that in my reply, was to remind you that your claim about water needs to be stated less ambivalently because water does behave in the way you say it doesn't under some circumstances.

The rest of your post is unintelligible. Maybe learn to use punctuation.
Edit: And proper words.

text:
Trakmatik But why is the sun going around your head during summer all the time? Why is that a thing all of a sudden? Are you suggesting that there is no night during summer?
But to answer your insane question as best as I can; the earth moves in a circular orbit around the sun, and the tilt of the earth changes in a set and well observed way as it travels in a full circle around the sun (which takes and is the basis for a year). At a certain point (in late June) the tilt of the earth is such that the northen hemisphere is tilted towards the sun, thus getting it the largest amount of sunlight, while the southern hemisphere gets the least, this is of course reversed come December, when the southern hemisphere has the most light and goes through summer whilst the northern hemisphere goes through winter.

Now, in regards to the whole gravity thing, I don't even know how to argue this, since you're basically saying any evidence to the existence of gravity is 'made up' or something (despite the fact you have no evidence of your own to provide an alternative to gravity, but whatever) but all I can attempt to say is that the sun is a globe, as are the rest of the celestial bodies in our solar system. This you can observe for yourself, just go buy a telescope and fucking look up. A fair reasoning that all these bodies are round is because gravity exists, no? And even if you were to somehow fail to see the logic in that, surely common sense would dictate that if every other observable celestial body is spherical than it should apply to Earth aswell. Furthermore, you can just get a glass, fill it with water, start spinning it around and then hold it upside down. The water will stay in the glass, this is an experiment kids do when they're like 8 come on, man. Water doesn't 'fall off' the earth because of the gravitational force of the centre of the earth, which everything on the Earth is pulled towards. There is absolutely no reason for things to 'fall off' the Earth because there is nothing pulling or pushing them away from its surface.

I mean there is alot more to address but most of what you're saying is either incredibly poorly worded or utter gibberish, probably caused by you attempting to use what you consider 'impressive language' to convince us all that you're smart.
That's the thing with flat earthers, you're all so stuck up in your own heads that you can't even concieve that someone knows something that you do not. That's the whole reason the flat earth movement exists, a bunch of questions that couldn't easily be answered with common knowledge were posed, of course most people didn't have the knowhow to answer these questions but actual trained proffessionals in the field did, and though most people didn't understand they were content to accept their findings. People like you also can't understand what they said, but the difference you're all such egomaniacs that you find it impossible to accept there are people that know more than you, that there are things you've never studied that you don't understand. text:
Trakmatik "They were statements without proof" except there is proof, except you just don't like the proof and therefore claim that it is invalid. We can mathematically prove beyond reasonable doubt that celestial bodies are spheres due to support from observations and how well it fits in with current theories in regards to how th e universe is formed. This is not just "being told" how things are and passively accepting it, this is being presented with theories and findings from experts in their fields, reviewing it, and going, "yes, this is the most plausible explanation for this and the evidence strongly suggests this to be true." Just because you're too lazy or stupid too do the revision yourself doesn't mean it doesn't exist.
Besides which what proof do you have that the Earth is flat? By your logic, you have literally know proof either, because I can just claim anything you claim to be proof is a "statement without proof".

"Do others know things I don't know? Yes." So you accept that there are people who know things you don't, but you refuse to believe that an astrologist, physicist, or geologist knows more than you on the nature of the planet? How does that work?

"You can only see one face of the Moon" If you get a powerful enough telescope (and I don't mean NASA level or anything, just a powerful commercial telescope) than you can see in detail the curvature of the moon, film that on a timelapse and you will see the moon turn. It really is that simple sometimes. Of course you don't accept this because you don't own a telescope, and any footage I present you with would be somehow fabricated so therefore you refute its existence.

"If it takes a year to go around the sun then halfway through the year we should be look out to a totally different night sky" I think this outlines pretty well that you have absolutely no clue what you're talking about. We do see the night sky differently throughout the year, constellations change and sometimes disappear altogether for a while, and the positions of the stars themselves change. I don't even know how to respond to this better than "yeah" because it's true and only serves to prove you've done no research of your own into this and are just spouting whatever you heard and whatever first comes to mind when presented with a contradiction.

"If the moon takes one month to go around the earth then you would never see a crecent moon at night and never see a gibbous or full moon during the day" ...and that's because why exactly? I'm not sure what you're talking about or how this has any relevance to the Moon or Earth being a sphere.

Ultimately flat earth "theory" makes no sense, and isn't backed by any scientific evidence, instead relying bizarrely on the possibility of the null hypothesis of a globe earth being true, and using that possibility as 'evidence'.
I mean, follow common sense, why would the government try to hide the fact that the Earth is flat? It must cost an exorbinate amount of money to do so.
Is it to hide the existence of God? But what would be the point of that? especially since Earth has been predominantly Christian/Islamic for its entire history, quite militantly aswell until very recently.
Is it to hide the existence of lands unknown beyond the 'ice wall'? Again to what avail? So people won't go there? Why is that such a threat? Surely various countries could have simply colonised the land and expanded both their power, influence and access to resources by revealing its existence.
The entire theory is a nonsensical byproduct of people believing they know everything in our society, with less and less trust being placed in those who actually specialise in the subjects covered.

Density is a fundamental concept in science, (true science) and you can see it throughout your life. Students, and even teachers, often confuse mass and density. The words heavy and light on their own refer to mass, and not density. For density, you also need to consider the size, or volume, of the object.
Before you can understand density you need to know about mass and volume.
Mass is the amount of matter in an object.
Mass is always measured on a balance.
Simply put, Volume is the space that matter takes up.

In fluid mechanics, the force density is the negative gradient of pressure. It has the physical dimensions of force per unit volume. Force density is a vector field representing the flux density of the hydrostatic force within the bulk of a fluid.

When an object is placed in a fluid, the fluid exerts an upward force we call the buoyant force. The buoyant force comes from the pressure exerted on the object by the fluid. Because the pressure increases as the depth increases, the pressure on the bottom of an object is always larger than the force on the top - hence the net upward force.

Buoyancy is the upward force caused by a fluid, such as water. This concept helps to explain why some things float while other objects sink. Buoyancy is an important factor in the design of many objects and in a number of water-based activities, such as boating or scuba diving.

This same idea helps to determine what will float in water and what will sink. If an object weighs more than the weight of the water it displaces, it will sink. If the object weighs less, it will float. This helps explain why a heavy ship can easily float in the water, while a much smaller and lighter brick will sink quickly. It isn't the size or shape of an object that primarily determines buoyancy, but the relation between an object's weight compared to the weight of the water the object displaces.


I do hope this education lesson has now enlightened you somewhat as too what density & buoyancy are, and why "gravity" has nothing whatsoever to do with either of them, and can only be found in dictionary's!!!

text:
1) Sunlight radiates and is proveably not parallel.

Sunlight indeed does radiate, scattering happens throughout the atmosphere, is measurable and follows a set model, see Rayleigh scattering. Experiments that you can do yourself at home confirm that the Rayleigh scattering model is accurate and is actually also used a lot in wireless telecommunications, so if you use a mobile phone, the interference model developed by Rayleigh allows us to understand and design systems around that. So, while light from the sun may not seem 100% parallel, light intensity is incredibly easy and increasingly more accurate to measure in modern day applications (you can buy light dependant resistors or transistors) which only matches the Sun being such a distance away.

2) Two plumbobs square to a level prove simultaneously there is no mass attraction and we are not on a sphere.

Have a look at the current law of universal gravitation and you will see why mass attraction only has visible effects in large masses. I'm quite happy to run you through the derivations if you'd like. Regardless of this fact, Cavendish used a torsion balance back in 1798 to derive the gravitational constant that we use today to an astounding degree of accuracy considering how long ago it was. This torsion balance used actual masses to see the force in laboratory conditions.


3) To use Geometry you need an axis x y level and plumb.  We can indeed verify both are straight and true.

There are many different kinds of geometry, geometry isn't a single principle, it's an entire mathematical field. The x, and y axis is just one type called the cartesian coordinate system (it doesn't actually need a plumb line for its definition, only an x and a y axis/point). On top of this there is also polar coordinate systems, cylindrical and spherical coordinate systems, among others. Coordinate systems can be interchanged and are done so in many applications in physics, mathematics and engineering, I'm happy to elaborate more on this if you'd like.

4) Once you can confirm the axis are both straight then you can use Geometry.  If you have no axis then how can you possibly use Geometry and what datum are you using?

The spherical system rather than an x, y and z system as you are probably used to uses a radius (distance from centre to the point), a polar angle and an azimuth angle instead. Regardless of this fact, you can convert and use both cartesian and spherical coordinate systems interchangeably and there are formulas for conversion.

5) There are no straight lines on a sphere.  If the earth was a sphere and you wanted to make something flat and level you would follow the curvature invert it then split the difference.  Of course noone does this because we do not live on a ball.

This is splitting hairs but the earth is actually an oblate spheroid not a sphere. Either way, it still has imperfections (mountains and valleys). Though in saying that, if you were to shrink the earth to the size of a basketball, for perspective, Mt Everest would only be 0.3mm off the surface of the basketball, you'd likely not even feel that with your finger if you ran it across. To make a flat surface on earth, we can still use the same method, pick two points and draw a line between them and you have a flat surface, this doesn't change at all. If you want it to be level, you can use a spirit level or a plumbob to check this just as you normally do, the earth being round doesn't change this at all. A large reason that it's so hard to comprehend is because of the sheer size difference between a human and the world, you can have locally flat areas, you can also have hilly areas, but this doesn't mean that as a whole, you can't have a round earth. Think about how large a square mile is, it's quite large, over the entire surface, you'd only have 2 inches of deviation on all sides from the centre over an entire mile. If you drop an ant in a warehouse, does he spend his entire life thinking that the entire world is flat, if you drop him on Mt Everest does he think the entire world is just one never ending hill with no highest point and no lowest point? Obviously local to him, this is all that he sees, all it takes is a look at the bigger picture. 

6) Without an axis geometry and vectoring will not work.

It most definitely does, it works in both coordinate systems and are interchangeable between both, most definitely have a look in a higher level maths textbook to learn about this. 

The verdict is most definitely decided on this one and the maths isn't even close to contended. Happy to answer any questions you have. Hope you have a good day.

(I'm legitimately curious about this - I have no idea how Flat-Earthers answer these questions)

Secondly, despite the fact that you say water always finds a level, I have never seen a flat body of water anywhere in my life. When I look at the ocean, I see a bumpy surface with waves and tides. I tell myself that it's the wind or the gravity of the moon - can you please explain this for me? When I travel by plane, the horizon looks curved - are all the flight companies in kahoots with the government to fool us?

When I place a drop of water on a "flat" tabletop, it doesn't seem to spread out and cover the surface in a flat film of water ... it's just sitting there in a roundish blob. When I pour myself a glass of water and set it down, I look at the surface and see that the water curves up against the edges of the glass. I has always thought that this was because of surface tension but now I realise that the water is also corrupt and working with the government to fool us all ... and it saddens me.

Perhaps it's more accurate to say that "water tries to find a level but has never quite managed to do so".

text:
You refereed to your sources as 90% of scientists. Or "most" climate experts. Not a single expert or independent scientist/Institute. NASA doesn't have the credibility as an unquestionable source, it's run by government . Great general sources. Please stick to comedy and don't talk nonsense. There is HUGE debate about climate change beetween climate experts and scientists and there is no majority at all. Most theories proving global warming fail miserably because they just can't create a relation beetween the normal climate change cycle and our impact(probably because there isn't). Big independent climate entities have not reached a decision, and are not even close because of politicians agenda to push "global warming". The only consensus is that greenhouse gases contribute to radioactive forcing and sulphate aerosols in the troposphere, but there is no proof whatsoever proving this irrefutably causes global warming. Even the IPCC admits they can't prove or refute climate sceptics because of "complexities and uncertainties of the science".   

1 - Climate change never resulted in mass extinctions. Natural cycles, landmass deformation and too much predators (this is way more common than you'd think) for example, are the cause and nothing else.  And yes, climate changes, literally every second, even before we existed.

2 - Temperatures ARE cooling in a lot of places, that's what climate change is, even before the agenda of global warming: the heat waves swap places, therefore new places become hotter, new places become cooler, especially noticeable on tropical countries (including mine) the past 3 summers have been an absolute joke. When I was younger I remember not being able to even breath in the summer of how hot it was, but we miss actually having Summer. Let's see if august is gonna finally be summer. 

Above centuries average, that I can believe and makes sense, still not a cause for concern. Simple methods of agricultural waste disposal and less lazy "let's dump it in the river it'll be fine" pretty much would fix our whole impact as humans species since the industrial era in less than 5 years, but it doesn't matter, you'd see climate like it is exactly today, we caused a difference of maybe a single degree celsius and 1 day of more or less summer/winter.

3 - The only impact we have as humans are the agricultural waste (bacteria consuming waste produce CO2) and animal farts. Heat waves will always eventually happen, so will cold weather, so will storms, so will tornados etc etc etc. 
The literal worst thing we may have caused is making climate a bit more unpredictable, as if climate was ever predictable to begin with.

author: Understanding Climate Change

text:
I'm glad you know the term radioactive forcing. However you seem slightly misinformed.
"Any factor that disturbs the radiation balance at the top of the atmosphere has the potential to 'force' the global climate to change: it will either warm up or cool down until a balance is restored."

So you used a theory widely used to challenge and question our impact in climate change (global warming)...to prove our impact in climate change....?

The term climate change is commonly used as a replacement for global warming, so that's what we are talking about, and that is what you were, misinformed, talking about as well "Every global surface temp dataset shows the last decade as the warmest on record" - that was your opening statement.

"Among the more enduring hypotheses to account for climate change are those based on the idea that the Sun is a variable star and that its output of energy varies through time. Indeed, this idea underlies the sceptical view that recent global warming has little to do with human activities; rather, the argument goes, solar variability is the main culprit."

These quotes are Intellectual property of The Open University, Walton Hall, Milton Keynes MK7 6AA. This was taken from research which is of a neutral stance, and the intent is only to challenge and test both climate change or lack thereof.

I'm however not a climate change denier entirely, but  this silly nonsensical doomsday apocalyptic idea of climate change is very much an unproven theory. Sure, we humans (in my opinion, after analyzing a lot of different data) undeniably impact the atmosphere (we're over 7 billion), but as I stated before, small impact, easy fix. Why is it not fixed? Because the impact is no more than an inconvenience, rather than actual danger.
author: insystem7

text:
I'm not misinformed about radiative forcing. Yes, radiative forcing balance can warm and cool. The year after Mt Pinatubu erupted, Earth cooled, then warmed again. Solar output does not explain the warming of the late 20th and early 21st century. There is no credible evidence to support this. Further, it can't explain the paleo record. Earth has been much warmer for most of its history yet the Sun has been less bright (Faint Young Sun Paradox). Episodes of a Snowball Earth etc
 "silly nonsensical doomsday apocalyptic idea of climate change is very much an unproven theory.' You mean 4-6 C above pre-industrial? That's the game we're playing, and we're 25% on our way....

author: David Guyette

text:
Goggle products 
"3 miles / 93 million miles"
Imagine an ant on a ping pong ball.
It sees, and feels(?) a curved surface. It can see the sun, (face it towards the sun!) But it can't see the other side of the ball.
Now imagine that ant on a beach ball (a REALLY big one!)
The ant can see the sun, it can see a circle of beach ball about 12" diameter (it's a big ball!).
The ants world is larger, it seems "flatter"
The bigger the ball, the larger the radius of the surface the ant can see. If the ball is big enough eventually the radius is so large it seems like a (virtually) straight line, flat.
The ant can still see the sun, it still can't see the other side of the ball, BUT, it COULD walk there!

I'm not a flat-earther.
The thing is, the earth is outragiously large. Even at 56.000 ft what you're seeing is just the horizon, you're not seeing the "edge" as you would from space.
If you stand on the ground you can see maybe a mile all around you. If you're high up in a plane you can see much, much further, but the length you can see is still less than the diameter of the earth.

When you see less than the diameter of the earth, you're just seeing the horizon curve around you. The curving horizon is a product of the earth being round, but you're not actually seeing the curve of the earth.

I'm not a flat-earther, the earth is obviously round, but I just wanted to clear up this misnomer.

text:
The ancient Greeks did discover that the world was round, but they certainly didn't always think that.  By the time of Eratosthenes, in the 3rd century BCE, it was certainly known that the world was round (he measured its circumference), but earlier geographers such as Hecataeus in the 6-5th century BCE portrays the world as flat, as do the Greek myths (which are older still). 
The probable truth is that, while the intellectual elite of the ancient world discovered that the world was round, the average farmer or peasant possibly thought that it was flat, but likely didn't even think about the shape of the whole planet at all

text: Fun fact: Columbus didn't actually think the world was pear shaped.  Maps back then were oriented so that east was on top, and always depicted a place of paradise, a garden of Eden, that existed at some point above the surface of the earth.  They also all showed a sort of bump, or nipple, at the very top of the map, just below this paradise.  Columbus thought he might approach that place by sailing over this swell in the shape of the planet that could theoretically send him there.  He only talked about it once, in a sort of whimsical, off the cuff manner, and from that, revisionists have claimed he said the earth was pear shaped with a stem like protuberance at the top.  He didn't.  There's a great video about him, debunking a lot of the claims that made him into the bad guy we seem to know today, on the Knowing Better channel if you're interested. He wasn't a saint, but he's gotten some seriously bad press, mostly from misinterpreted and out of context info like this.

text:
I'll end this debate once and for all!  Don't even attempt to respond unless you understand every single aspect as I do because I WILL prove you wrong!!!  You also better read every single word before spouting your theoretical bullshit or stupidity because I can spot either a mile a way.  Don't do like all other morons and ignore the first part of my argument either:

You want the truth but you can't handle the truth without insults or criticism...

Some choose to follow the side of religion while some choose to follow the side of science.  I follow truth, logic, reason and common sense.  Truth, the infallible facts.  Logic, yes or no, but not always answerable with either. Reason, the power of the mind to think, understand, and form judgments.  Common sense, sound and prudent judgment based on a simple perception of the situation or facts.  Both Science and Religion are nothing more than a means to an end and they are both oh so wrong. It can easily be proven, but what is proof?

Proof is in the eye of the beholder...

There are logical proofs, mathematical proofs, pathological proofs, empirical proofs, implied proofs and varied combinations. Each kind of proof assumes that a reader is skilled at the proof type such that they will be affected by the proof into persuasion.

A logic proof assumes that the reader is skilled enough in logic to see the validity being presented. The mathematical proof assumes that the reader is skilled at math. The pathological proof assumes that the reader is emotionally persuaded. The empirical proof assumes that the reader is skilled at analytical observation. The implied proof is based on what is known but not presented.

But when a proof is given and the reader declares that it is invalid, how does the reader or the poster know whether the perceived invalidity is due to actual invalidity or merely that the reader is not skilled enough in that type of proof? When the reader rebuts the proof, the reader is presuming that he is indeed skilled at the type of proof being presented, just as-the poster presumes that he was skilled enough to present such a proof type.

Or in addition, perhaps the poster and the reader are skilled in the proof type, but either the poster is not skilled at expressing himself in writing, or the reader is simply not very skilled at comprehending what he reads.

How is one to determine wherein the difficulty lies?

In any of the cases of rebuttal, if the respondent merely proclaims that the proof is invalid and doesn‚Äôt attempt to point to the exact detail of fallacy, he is merely being confrontational rather than constructive. Thus not giving detail in a rebuttal is clearly not helpful whether the proof is valid or not.

But even if detail is given and the original poster proclaims that the respondent is wrong, what then?

Perhaps in the proof a poster had made an assertion and a respondent proclaims, ‚Äúthat is subjective‚Äù then the poster replies, ‚Äúno it isn‚Äôt‚Äù. Who is really at fault? Or perhaps the poster has given what he thought was a seriously moving story, but he sees a respondent say, ‚ÄúWell, that‚Äôs just silly‚Äù? or "You need mental Help"? or how about "You don't know what you are talking about and haven't proved shit!"?

In a political arena, any rebuttal is an attempt to persuade other readers regardless of actual truth value and a varied means of persuasion is likely to be used. This leads to a very complex situation of multiple types of proofs being simultaneously debated because the effort is not to resolve, but to bring down the opponent.

How does the poster or the respondent really know who was less skilled at the art of persuasion especially if multiple modes of proof were provided??

Let us see...

text:
Guybrush Threepwood Gravity is the force masses have and it attracts other masses. It's weak so we only see it on giant masses like a planet. The water  filling that container is just being pulled towards the earth (downwards). Water and any liquid is going to take the shape the forces acting on it cause it to take. The forces on water in a container would be gravity pulling it down, and reaction force from the container holding the water in the container hence why it takes the shape of the container. How does gravity only hold oceans but not bugs? Gravity affects bigger masses more that smaller masses therefore bugs have a reduced force pulling them down compared to a giant ocean. Plus, bugs have wings to counteract gravity whereas oceans have nothing to propel themselves off of the planet.

On the topic of planes: if you jumped in a moving bus/train, are you suddenly hit the back? No, because your body is moving at the same speed as the vehicle. That's how planes work. That's how the planet moves so fast without killing us. It's not speed that matters but rather a change in speed that affects us. Everything on the Earth is moving with the Earth which is why planes actually need to move forward in the air on a globe.

The reason people believe in the globe earth is because it explains everything. We've predicted eclipses and events whereas I can't even find a flat earth model that explains lunar eclipses/blood moons and arctic day night cycles. This is all ignoring how there's no reason to lie, the absence of any other flat masses in space, the necessities to convince thousands of people to lie, the money spent on space technology globally, the lack of an actual to scale flat earth model that actually works with what has been observed as well as so many issues.

The globe explains everything. Give me a flat earth model (to scale) that explains everything and that everyone agrees on like us globe heads have done, then maybe people will listen.

As your elevation increases the air gets thinner if you dispute that much you're 100% a troll this is why airplanes are pressurized and why mountain climbers bring extra oxygen with them when climbing tall mountains. The atmosphere gets less dense because gravitys effect is reduced the further away from the center of mass the matter its effect is measured on is.  

you also say we have no proof for the claims of the suns distance from earth or how big it is I figured id give you a less common way we can demonstrate proof of these claims. We have solar panels on earth that convert thermal energy and radiant light we know how much energy these panels can generate at a given size over a set time. We also know and can test/demonstrate how far light and radiation can travel and how distance from source, the atmospheric make, up and angle of light, effects its intensity. We also have the ability to measure how much energy the fusing of different atoms generates with that data we can then extrapolate out the distance and mass of stars this result matches the the claimed size and distance we get from the standard measurement models done with radio signals. Don't know why you would need more evidence then just radio signal measurements though since I know you're aware that we understand radio waves and how fast they travel and all we do for distance to (relatively close) stellar objects is time how long it takes for it to make a round trip that really can't be misinterpreted.

The idea is that objects with mass attract towards other objects of mass this is not limited to 2 OoM the attractive force of gravity has infinite range and all OoM in the universe generate an attractive force with each other the force is greatly reduced (inverse square of distance) the further apart the OoM are from one another so you will see a stronger attraction between objects near one another other factors contributing to the strength of attraction are position relative to center of mass of the largest local mass and the mass of the objects you are calculating an attraction on.

text: The reason why air doesn't escape into the vacuum is quite interesting and something even most Roundworld proponents don't explain correctly: If the average velocity of a particular gas's molecules is higher than the escape velocity of a particular planet then that gas quickly escapes into the surrounding vacuum, if it isn't then it doesn't. This explains the atmospheric composition of the planets; Jupiter, with its high gravity, holds onto the lighter, zippier gasses like hydrogen and helium, whereas Earth can only hold onto the more sluggish, heavier gasses like oxygen and nitrogen. One interesting and downright scary consequence of this is that, because water is dissociated into hydrogen and oxygen by sunlight and that hydrogen escapes the Earth, and because the Sun is gradually getting hotter water is actually slowly leaking away into space at such a rate that in 800 million years most of it'll be gone and Earth will be a lifeless desert planet. This is a shockingly short time geologically speaking and another great reason to get the hell off this rock. I refuse to respond to people like Guybrush Threepwood for many of'em are just trolls, and the True Believers are unreachable because Flearthism really is a form of religion and as such its adherents will just keep reciting the dogma their fake prophets like Jeranism, who well and truly know the Earth's spherical but keep up the pretense for personal gain, have taught them, without ever exploring the very easy answers to their dogmatic questions which are handed to them on a silver platter by the sadly misguided people who actually think they might have a tiny chance of getting through to a Flearther. Unfortunately, YouTube's comments section, like most 'social' media, is expressly designed to foster division and hate; their entire platforms encourage the creation of crazy conflicting ideas in order to waste people's time, energy and effort, preventing them from uniting and focusing their combined power on dismantling the system of control that allows the very few who own the power to take it from the many that make it to produce the greatest inequality in history. text:
Ok, I‚Äôve just read over 200 comments, many of them from flat earthers repeating their incredulity and lack of understanding. They claim anyone who believes in science is a mindless sheep forgetting that their modern lives rely on science. 

Could I point out one thing said in one comment by one flat earther that shows very clearly what we are dealing with, a comment I am surprised wasn‚Äôt immediately countered. It is the one in which the claim was made that the globe is 70% water. No, it isn‚Äôt. A little over 70% of the surface is covered in water. It is a very small amount of the total mass of our planet. 

Maybe the commenter just got their comment mixed up and they know the truth, but the fact remains this is a common statement made by flat earthers, as is the water always level nonsense. Tides, anyone? How do they work? If the water is low in one place and high in another, how on earth is it level? 

Flat earthers say we can‚Äôt prove anything while not being able to prove anything.

text: No, pixel girl, I understand where you're coming from - I used to be a deist because my instinct genuinely led me to believe that non-boolean logic (assuming a set of more than two possible values) was applicable to the question of whether I believed a deity existed - but when you come to realise the only intellectually honest and practical definition of agnosticism concerns 'knowledge', which it does considering its Greek etymology (gn√¥sis = knowledge), and should therefore be distinct from those like 'theist' and 'atheist', which concern belief (Plato made a big deal about the former/knowledge being a distinct subset of the latter/belief), the only honest permutation of these terms you, as an honest logician, should label yourself, is agnostic atheist. Using nebulous definitions when trying to formulate one's wordview isn't helpful if one needs to argue one's position or wishes to employ coherent logic and have commensurately well-reasoned beliefs. It's important that we not confuse arguments with sloppy definitions just because an idea is a compelling one, or just because a certain definition is used colloquially. We don't have other universes we can measure to compare this one to, or the necessary features of a deity, so we can't tell the probability of one existing, so the null position is more logical than that of believing in an unfalsifiable hypothesis with 0 explanatory power. The courtroom analogy and the necessary logical and practical distinction between Guilt, Non-Guilt, and Innocence is a useful one. In my disbelief I find god Not Guilty of existing. For clarity‚Äôs sake, Guilt and Non-Guilt in this analogy corresponds with Belief and Non-Belief, respectively, and Innocence with knowledge, or more specifically agnostic (if a courtroom were set up in reverse where Guilt was the default then it would equate to gnostic). God is innocent of existing until proven guilty. As such, agnosticism is the default position, and the only logical, or reasonable, verdict is atheist. You can't just declare a mistrial every time there's insufficient evidence of guilt. In my disbelief I find god Not Guilty of existing. Sorry if I sound condescending, but this 'mistrial' mentality is the MO of the typical self-proclaimed ‚Äòagnostic‚Äô.

text:
Andrew Gallacher: What you are saying is true, human emissions are indeed only a small portion when compared with natural emissions. The important thing is, the human ones weren't there before. 

It's best to think of the carbon cycle as like weighing scales, a certain amount of CO2 is emitted globally per year, and a certain amount absorbed per year. Like a weighing scale, you don't have to put even close to 5% of the total weights in the scale to tip the scales. That's precisely what's happening with climate change, the scales were roughly balanced before, the same amount of CO2 was being absorbed as emitted. With human activity that is no longer the case.

I recommend this videa amongst others the author has made, he always includes the scientific literature amongst the videos and is pretty good at explaining things: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CcmCBetoR18

I don't get why people seem to think they understand a complicated science better than people who've studied it for sometimes decades. Would you think for a second that you are better at surgery than a surgeon? Why is it different with any other expert in their field. I do recommend watching that video if you have an open mind.

text: "The Keeling curve would tell us there was virtually no CO2 in Hawaii previous to the 20th century." What nonsense.  The Mauna Loa measurements only started in the 1950's. Atmospheric CO2 is a globalized signal because the atmospheric gases mix over time . Hawaii CO2 is no different to that at other stations +- 2-3ppm   If you don't like Hawaii, check out Cape Grim in Tasmania or the European stations in the Alps or any of the other dozens of CO2 recording stations around the planet. The Keeling Curve tells us nothing prior to the 1950's. For pre-1950 we use proxy data. And for the last 1 million years at least CO2 hasn't been above 280ppm until the last century. According to your argument, that means for the last 100 years the planet has seen unprecedented volcanic activity, not seen in the last 1 million years which is quite remarkable.

You can stick your head in the sand if you like along with the rest of the "I don't do politics, me/they're all the same" sheep who's complacency/apathy has allowed things to get this bad.

author: Widdekuu91

text: ¬†@Richard Nowell¬† It was a reference to her eyes being wet from tears in the context of similes for "as dry as". Somehow you have interpreted something very sinister from this exchange. Shows where your distorted mind is. She could have been crying for numerous different reasons. Tears of joy, love, disappointment, pain, pleasure. The inference from Richard Ayoade's joke is that she was crying in disappointment or displeasure. It is very unlikely a man could be accused or successfully prosecuted with rape on his wedding night unless he was physically violent and coercive such as using a weapon.  If a woman is a virgin on her wedding night it is expected that during intercourse there will be some discomfort. it may be painful enough to induce tears in the woman and it may not be a pleasant experience. Rather than being an inappropriate joke trivializing unpleasant sexual intercourse from a moral point or forced intercourse constituting rape, it was a big dig at Donald Trump's apparent lack of sexual appeal and inadequacy as a compassionate lover. You can't look at every unpleasant sexual experience through rape colored glasses.
